title: Tottenham's mess is result of underlying issues - and greedy egos are to blame
text:

It is clearer than ever Tottenham are in a real mess. They’re just not the same team, there isn’t the same togetherness as last season.

The body language is different – from the manager right through to some of their most senior and important ­players – and that can’t be right.

Inevitably, we’ve heard so many ­rumours about problems and bust-ups, about players not wanting to play, even about the manager giving up.

I don’t believe that because I think to get to the level Pochettino has achieved you need a drive and an ego that means you never chuck it in, whether you want to leave or not.

For me, though, it IS about ego. It’s a fundamental problem that’s long been coming. I’ve seen it so many times in football, and it’s always based around ego.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

You get players –you get teams – who when they start winning, start to believe all the BS that pours out – and some of the people involved start to get a bit greedy.

I’m not talking about money ­specifically here, though that can always be a problem, I’m ­talking more about that view people get about themselves when things are going well.

It’s a sense of self-­importance.

I’ve seen it myself in my own career, though never on the scale Spurs are experiencing. There were players at Liverpool who thought they were better than they ­really were – and got carried along by that.

It’s such a strange sport.

It’s a team game based on the talents of the individual.

(Image: Mark Pain/PA Images Contributor)

Sides like City and ­Liverpool – and I’d put the Spurs of last season in this category – no matter how good their “stars” are, they are still a collective greater than the sum of their parts.

Yet you are rewarded ­individually, and the biggest ­rewards go to the biggest stars.

I see at Spurs players getting greedy, not just for what they can earn, but for acclaim too.

I have to say, ­Tottenham have found themselves in an almost weird situation. How many players are in the last year of their contract, and big players too? Three, and another four with only 18 months left.

That’s mad.

(Image: PA)

When you have Alderweireld, Eriksen and Vertonghen all in the final year of their contracts, and all variously left out at some point or other, it is clearly getting toxic.

Then add in important players like Rose and Dier also close to the end, it’s not right. Why? It’s so rare for that to happen, and you can ­perhaps look at the chairman Daniel Levy and say maybe he’s been found out, maybe his cunning strategies to keep costs down have finally caught up with him.

Maybe it’s just like Arsenal where they built a stadium and couldn’t spend on players’ wages.

Or maybe, just maybe, there are other underlying reasons.

(Image: Mark Pain/PA Images Contributor)

You can’t sugar-coat it. When you get a situation like this, there are always issues at the heart of it. It could be greed, it could be bad faith, it could be the club is a mess and players want out.

When the manager wants out too, that gets the alarm bells ringing for me.

I can’t believe so many want out ­without a fundamental issue that ­suggests it’s toxic.

I’m old-fashioned, though.

(Image: Mark Pain/PA Images Contributor)

When I signed a contract, I believed in that club and wanted in. I only ever wanted out when I wasn’t playing – which is why I left Liverpool.

So I’ll come back to what I said at the start. Sometimes, people just get greedy in football.

And whoever is to blame at ­Tottenham, whether it be the manager, the ­players or the chairman (and all have been blamed, haven’t they?), they need to have a long hard look at themselves.
